channel.title: Comments on: How to change the SA password in SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Alex Franky
item.dc:creator: Alex Franky
item.description: I suggest you the right and uncomplicated way to update SQL SA password is to use <strong>MS SQL password recovery software</strong>. With this SQL password recovery tool you can reset the SQL SA password and User password easily in few click of mouse. Try this from here :: <a href="http://sonikarawat.wordpress.com/2014/07/01/how-to-unlock-sql-server-account/" rel="nofollow">http://sonikarawat.wordpress.com/2014/07/01/how-to-unlock-sql-server-account/</a>
item.content:encoded: I suggest you the right and uncomplicated way to update SQL SA password is to use MS SQL password recovery software. With this SQL password recovery tool you can reset the SQL SA password and User password easily in few click of mouse. Try this from here :: http://sonikarawat.wordpress.com/2014/07/01/how-to-unlock-sql-server-account/

item.title: By: Joe
item.dc:creator: Joe
item.description: I couldn't connect to SQL Server because the Windows authentication is disabled and SA account is also locked out. Eventually I managed to unlock SA account using a paid software - SQL Server Password Changer. It's worth a try.
item.content:encoded: I couldn’t connect to SQL Server because the Windows authentication is disabled and SA account is also locked out. Eventually I managed to unlock SA account using a paid software – SQL Server Password Changer. It’s worth a try.

item.title: By: Rajit Venkatesh
item.dc:creator: Rajit Venkatesh
item.description: That changes the password for only 1 SA account. How do you do this for all the SA accounts of all the DB in all the Servers in a corporate network?
item.content:encoded: That changes the password for only 1 SA account. How do you do this for all the SA accounts of all the DB in all the Servers in a corporate network?

item.title: By: jhenrichs
item.dc:creator: jhenrichs
item.description: When "all your DBA's are killed", you're in big trouble.<br /> Make sure you are a local admin on the machine. Then, look up how to start SQL in single user mode. In this mode, I believe the local admins become SA on the SQL.
item.content:encoded:
When “all your DBA’s are killed”, you’re in big trouble.
Make sure you are a local admin on the machine. Then, look up how to start SQL in single user mode. In this mode, I believe the local admins become SA on the SQL.

item.title: By: Brij Sharma
item.dc:creator: Brij Sharma
item.description: Never new that I could change passwords like that. Thanks a lot.
item.content:encoded: Never new that I could change passwords like that. Thanks a lot.

item.title: By: SQLArcher
item.dc:creator: SQLArcher
item.content:encoded:
Good post. However looking at a solution like SQL Server Core, or even some of the current versions, how would you get passed the SA password issue when you have no rights within SQL Server.

An example would be a very bad disaster scenario where all your DBA’s are killed, and a someone else needs to try and recover SQL Server. Any suggestions?
